    • Field Detail

      • limitingAxes

        protected AbstractAxes limitingAxes

      • limitCones

        protected java.util.ArrayList<AbstractLimitCone> limitCones
        An array containing all of the KusudamaExample's limitCones. The kusudama is built up with the expectation that any limitCone in the array is connected to the cone at the previous element in the array, and the cone at the next element in the array.

      • minAxialAngle

        protected double minAxialAngle
        Defined as some Angle in radians about the limitingAxes Y axis, 0 being equivalent to the limitingAxes Z axis.

      • range

        protected double range
        Defined as some Angle in radians about the limitingAxes Y axis, 0 being equivalent to the minAxialAngle

      • orientationallyConstrained

        protected boolean orientationallyConstrained

      • axiallyConstrained

        protected boolean axiallyConstrained

        protected AbstractAxes baseInverseLimitingAxes

      • inverseLimitingAxes

        protected AbstractAxes inverseLimitingAxes
        autogenerated to be same as limitingAxes, and parented to limitingAxes but with an inverted y-component. used in order to check limits backwards from the parent tip to the parent base.

      • autoOptimize

        protected boolean autoOptimize
        If true, automatically reOrients the limitingAxes to minimize potential for rotational degeneracies.

      • constraintUpdateNotification

        public void constraintUpdateNotification()

      • optimizeLimitingAxes

        public void optimizeLimitingAxes()

      • recomputeBaseInverseLimitAxes

        public void recomputeBaseInverseLimitAxes()
        regenerates the baseInverseLimitingAxes (which are attached to the limitingAxes and) used to calculate the swing component of the inverseLimitingAxes (which are attached to the bone's localAxes). This function should be called after any changes are made to the limitingAxes. updateInverseLimitingAxes() should always be called after any changes to the orientation of the bone to which this kusudama is attached, so that the inverseLimitingAxes can discard twist component of their rotation relative to to the baseInverseLimitingAxes.

      • setAxesToInverseLimitingAxes

                                         AbstractAxes toSet)

        public void snapToInvertedTwistLimit​(AbstractAxes boneAxes,

      • snapToInvertedLimit

        public void snapToInvertedLimit​(AbstractAxes boneAxes,
                                AbstractAxes startParentBoneAxes,
                                AbstractAxes newParentBoneAxes,
                                AbstractAxes simulatedInverseLimitingAxes,
                                AbstractAxes toSet,
                                boolean snapTwist,
                                boolean snapOrientation)
        !!CAUTION: this function should only be called if startParentBoneAxes, boneAxes and newParentBoneAxes are such that the parentBone's tip is on the boneAxes base. Given a set of Axes representing the localAxes of the bone to which this kusudama is attached @param boneAxes, and a set of Axes representing the localAxes of that bone's parent @param startParentBoneAxes, determines if setting the parentBoneAxes to @param newParentBoneAxes would result in a violation of the constraint on this bone, and if they do, sets @param toSet to be equivalent to the position / orientation of the parent bone rectified to be in constraint limits in global coordinates. If the parent bone has a parent, the localAxes of the value are updated so that they correspond to the bone axes new location This is useful primarily for orientation aware IK solvers.
        Parameters:
        boneAxes -
        startParentBoneAxes -
        newParentBoneAxes -
        simulatedInverseLimitingAxes - a preComputed inverselimitingAxes, already oriented as it would have been prior to any rotation of the parent bone
        the - axes to snap

      • setAutoOptimizeConstraintOrientationBasis

        public void setAutoOptimizeConstraintOrientationBasis​(boolean b)
        if true (default), the axes relative to which constraints are computed will be automatically reoriented on any changes in LimitCone position so as to minimize the potential for undesirable twist rotations. In general, auto-optimization attempts to point the y-component of the constraint axes in the direction that places it within in an oreintation allowed by the constraint, and roughly as far as possible from any orientations not allowed by the constraint.
        Parameters:
        b -

      • setAxialLimits

        public void setAxialLimits​(double minAngle,
                           double inRange)
        KusudamaExample constraints decompose the bone orientation into a swing component, and a twist component. The "Swing" component is the final direction of the bone. The "Twist" component represents how much the bone is rotated about its own final direction. Where limit cones allow you to constrain the "Swing" component, this method lets you constrain the "twist" component.
        Parameters:
        minAnlge - some angle in radians about the major rotation frame's y-axis to serve as the first angle within the range that the bone is allowed to twist.
        inRange - some angle in radians added to the minAngle. if the bone's local Z goes maxAngle radians beyond the minAngle, it is considered past the limit. This value is always interpreted as being in the positive direction. For example, if this value is -PI/2, the entire range from minAngle to minAngle + 3PI/4 is considered valid.

      • snapToTwistLimits

        public double snapToTwistLimits​(AbstractAxes toSet,
                                AbstractAxes limitingAxes)
        Parameters:
        toSet -
        limitingAxes -
        Returns:
        radians of twist required to snap bone into twist limits (0 if bone is already in twist limits)

      • signedAngleDifference

        public double signedAngleDifference​(double minAngle,
                                    double base)

      • pointInLimits

        public SGVec_3d pointInLimits​(SGVec_3d inPoint,
                              double[] inBounds,
                              AbstractAxes limitingAxes)
        Given a point (in global coordinates), checks to see if a ray can be extended from the KusudamaExample's origin to that point, such that the ray in the KusudamaExample's reference frame is within the range allowed by the KusudamaExample's coneLimits. If such a ray exists, the original point is returned (the point is within the limits). If it cannot exist, the tip of the ray within the kusudama's limits that would require the least rotation to arrive at the input point is returned.
        Parameters:
        inPoint - the point to test.
        returns - a number from -1 to 1 representing the point's distance from the boundary, 0 means the point is right on the boundary, 1 means the point is within the boundary and on the path furthest from the boundary. any negative number means the point is outside of the boundary, but does not signify anything about how far from the boundary the point is.
        Returns:
        the original point, if it's in limits, or the closest point which is in limits.

      • getPenaltyRotationAt

        public void getPenaltyRotationAt​(SGVec_3d startPoint,
                                 SGVec_3d goalPoint)
        Given a start and end point (in local coordinates), build a rotation to take the start point to the end point, then computes a penalty on the rotation such that the end point does not exceed the kusudama's limits and avoids rotation toward those limits in proportion to the point's distance to those limits. If such a ray exists, the original point is returned (the point is within the limits). If it cannot exist, the tip of the ray within the kusudama's limits that would require the least rotation to arrive at the input point is returned.
        Parameters:
        inPoint - the point to test.
        returns - a number from -1 to 1 representing the point's distance from the boundary, 0 means the point is right on the boundary, 1 means the point is within the boundary and on the path furthest from the boundary. any negative number means the point is outside of the boundary, but does not signify anything about how far from the boundary the point is.

      • pointInLocalLimits

        public SGVec_3d pointInLocalLimits​(SGVec_3d inPoint,
                                   double[] inBounds)
        Given a point (in local coordinates), checks to see if a ray can be extended from the KusudamaExample's origin to that point, such that the ray in the KusudamaExample's reference frame is within the range allowed by the KusudamaExample's coneLimits. If such a ray exists, the original point is returned (the point is within the limits). If it cannot exist, the tip of the ray within the kusudama's limits that would require the least rotation to arrive at the input point is returned.
        Parameters:
        inPoint - the point to test.
        returns - a number from -1 to 1 representing the point's distance from the boundary, 0 means the point is right on the boundary, 1 means the point is within the boundary and on the path furthest from the boundary. any negative number means the point is outside of the boundary, but does not signify anything about how far from the boundary the point is.
        Returns:
        the original point, if it's in limits, or the closest point which is in limits.

        public SGVec_3d pointInSoftBound​(SGVec_3d currentPosition_global,

                                 AbstractAxes limitingAxes)
        Given a point representing the tip of this bone in local coordinates prior to rotation and a point representing the tip of this bone in local coordinates after rotation returns the point where it would be after penalizing the portion of the rotation moving toward the nearest boundary.
        Parameters:
        previousPosition -
        currentPosition -
        Returns:

      • attachedTo

        public AbstractBone attachedTo()

      • addLimitCone

        public void addLimitCone​(SGVec_3d newPoint,
                         double radius,
                         AbstractLimitCone previous,
                         AbstractLimitCone next)
        Add a LimitCone to the KusudamaExample.
        Parameters:
        newPoint - where on the KusudamaExample to add the LimitCone (in KusudamaExample's local coordinate frame defined by its bone's majorRotationAxes))
        radius - the radius of the limitCone
        previous - the LimitCone adjacent to this one (may be null if LimitCone is not supposed to be between two existing LimitCones)
        next - the other LimitCone adjacent to this one (may be null if LimitCone is not supposed to be between two existing LimitCones)

      • removeLimitCone

        public void removeLimitCone​(AbstractLimitCone limitCone)

      • createLimitConeForIndex

        public abstract AbstractLimitCone createLimitConeForIndex​(int insertAt,
                                                          SGVec_3d newPoint,
                                                          double radius)

      • addLimitConeAtIndex

        public void addLimitConeAtIndex​(int insertAt,
                                SGVec_3d newPoint,
                                double radius)
        Adds a LimitCone to the KusudamaExample. LimitCones are reach cones which can be arranged sequentially. The KusudamaExample will infer a smooth path leading from one LimitCone to the next. Using a single LimitCone is functionally equivalent to a classic reachCone constraint.
        Parameters:
        insertAt - the intended index for this LimitCone in the sequence of LimitCones from which the KusudamaExample will infer a path. @see IK.AbstractKusudama.limitCones limitCones array.
        newPoint - where on the KusudamaExample to add the LimitCone (in KusudamaExample's local coordinate frame defined by its bone's majorRotationAxes))
        radius - the radius of the limitCone

      • limitingAxes

        public AbstractAxes limitingAxes()
        Specified by:
        limitingAxes in interface Constraint
        Returns:
        the limitingAxes of this KusudamaExample (these are just its parentBone's majorRotationAxes)

      • getRotationalFreedom

        public double getRotationalFreedom()
        TODO: // this functionality is not yet fully implemented It always returns an overly simplistic representation not in line with what is described below.
        Specified by:
        getRotationalFreedom in interface Constraint
        Returns:
        an (approximate) measure of the amount of rotational freedom afforded by this kusudama, with 0 meaning no rotational freedom, and 1 meaning total unconstrained freedom. This is approximately computed as a ratio between the orientations the bone can be in vs the orientations it cannot be in. Note that unfortunately this function double counts the orientations a bone can be in between two limit cones in a sequence if those limit cones intersect with a previous sequence.

      • updateRotationalFreedom

        protected void updateRotationalFreedom()

      • attachTo

        public void attachTo​(AbstractBone forBone)
        attaches the KusudamaExample to the BoneExample. If the kusudama has its own limiting axes specified, replaces the bone's major rotation axes with the Kusudamas limiting axes. otherwise, this function will set the kusudama's limiting axes to the major rotation axes specified by the bone.
        Parameters:
        forBone - the bone to which to attach this KusudamaExample.

      • setStrength

        public void setStrength​(double newStrength)
        for IK solvers. Defines the weight ratio between the unconstrained IK solved orientation and the constrained orientation for this bone per iteration. This should help stabilize solutions somewhat by allowing for soft constraint violations.
        Parameters:
        strength - a value between 0 and 1. Any other value will be clamped to this range.

      • getStrength

        public double getStrength()
        for IK solvers. Defines the weight ratio between the unconstrained IK solved orientation and the constrained orientation for this bone per iteration. This should help stabilize solutions somewhat by allowing for soft constraint violations.

      • getLimitCones

        public java.util.ArrayList<? extends AbstractLimitCone> getLimitCones()
